did.abstract: Karen Stamm was an activist in the women's health and reproductive righs movements of the 1970s and 1980s, notably through her role in the Committee to End Sterilization Abuse (CESA) and its successor, the Committee for Abortion Rights and Against Sterilization Abuse (CARASA). Stamm helped found and at some point chaired committees in both organizations. The Papers document those struggles for reproductive freedom and equality, particularly the activities of the Committee to End Sterilization Abuse (CESA) and its successor, the Committee for Abortion Rights and Against Sterilization Abuse (CARASA). In addition to minutes and agendas, correspondence, research and resource files, legislative and lobbying campaign materials, newsletters, pamphlets, and other educational and advocacy materials from CESA and CARASA, there is a mix of materials, mostly newsletters, publications, pamphlets and correspondence of member organizations, organizations they have worked in coalition with, and organizations that have opposed them are also part of the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is unprocessed, and un-arranged. However, there is a detailed box-level inventory for the first thirteen boxes of the collection.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Gift of Karen Stamm. The accession number associated with this gift is 1999.018. In 2012, an oral history with Karen Stamm, conducted by Tamar Carroll, was added to the collection. The accession number for this interview is 2014.108.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Karen Stamm was an activist in the women's health and reproductive righs movements of the 1970s and 1980s, notably through her role in the Committee to End Sterilization Abuse (CESA) and its successor, the Committee for Abortion Rights and Against Sterilization Abuse (CARASA). Karen Stamm helped found and at some point chaired committees in both organizations. Both CESA and CARASA were committed to creating a more inclusive reproductive rights movement that took into account the fact that all women did not have equal control of their reproduction and that this choice was in fact limited by race and class. Both rejected the notion that overpopulation was the cause of social and economic ills, called for the end of sterilization abuse as a means of population control, and advocated for the economic conditions that were necessary to undergird economically disadvantaged women’s right to choose freely.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collections documents the 1970s and 1980s struggles for reproductive freedom and equality fought by women's health conditions, particularly the Committee to End Sterilization Abuse (CESA) and its successor, the Committee for Abortion Rights and Against Sterilization Abuse (CARASA). The collection ranges in date from 1946 to 1992, but the bulk of materials date from the 1970s and 1980s. In addition to statements of purpose, meeting minutes and agendas, correspondence, research and resource files, legislative and lobbying campaign materials, newsletters, pamphlets, and other educational and advocacy materials from CESA and CARASA, a mix of materials, mostly newsletters, publications, pamphlets and correspondence of member organizations, organizations they have worked in coalition with, and organizations that have opposed them are also part of the collection. These include the National Women’s Health Network, the Center for Constitutional Rights, the Reproductive Rights National Network, the New York City Health and Hospital Corporation, the Health Policy Advisory Center, the American Civil Liberties Union, the Coalition for the Reproductive Rights of Workers, New York Committee for Occupational Safety and Health, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, the Association for Voluntary Sterilization, Planned Parenthood, and the US Department of Health, Education and Welfare. A large part of the collection consists of newspaper and article clipping files relating mostly to various aspects of sterilization, such as abuse, informed consent, eugenic sterilization, popular and medical attitudes, racial discrimination, and statistics, but also abortion, reproductive rights in the workplace, population control, AIDS, and other health topics.

ACLU-American Civil Liberties Union; AVS-Association for Voluntary Sterilization; CARASA-Committee for Abortion Rights and Against Sterilization Abuse; CESA-Committee to End Sterilization Abuse; CCR-Center for Constitutional Rights; CRROW-Coalition for the Reproductive Rights of Workers; Health/PAC-Health Policy Advisory Center KS-Karen Stamm; (D)HEW-US Dept. of Health, Education and Welfare; NWHN-National Women’s Health Network; NYC HHC-New York City Health and Hospital Corporation; NYCOSH-New York Committee for Occupational Safety and Health; R2N2-Reproductive Rights National Network

odd.p: Preservation Note: A few of the more fragile clippings are in folders but most are loose. Please handle with care.

News clippings mostly taken from the New York Times and cover a range of topics from a scarcity of staple black beans in Brazil, the national grain reserve, a surge in Mexican illegal immigration, and ethical questions re: the CIA’s mind control experiment.

Contains a mix of materials relating to a range of women’s health subjects, including sterilization abuse and regulations, birth control research, workplace discrimination as it relates to forced sterilization, Abortion Rights Week organizing, and intrauterine Diethylstilbestrol (DES) exposure. Materials range in date from 1976 to 1982 and include correspondence, newsletters, factsheets, brochures, press releases, drafts of position papers, and medical research papers. Organizations represented include CARASA, NY Inco for DES Action, CESA, the Consumer Commission on Accreditation of Health Services, and the Coalition for the Medical Rights of Women.
